key_points: The Wall Street Journal's 'Facebook Files' series reveals internal Facebook research on the platform's negative impacts.
Documents show Facebook's awareness of problems like misinformation but a lack of action to resolve them.
The XCheck program exempted high-profile users from Facebook's rules, allowing misinformation and harmful content.
Less than 10% of flagged posts under the XCheck program were reviewed.
Internal research found Instagram harms teens' mental health, particularly among girls, leading to body image issues and depression.
Facebook downplayed its own research showing Instagram's negative effects and did not make findings public.
Instagram for kids development continues despite backlash and concerns over children's mental health.
A 2018 Facebook algorithm change intended to improve user interaction actually amplified divisive and harmful content.
Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg resisted fixes to divisive content amplification fearing decreased user engagement.
Facebook claims it has integrity teams working to mitigate issues caused by its algorithms.
spokespersons: Lars Backstrom (Vice President of Engineering, Facebook)
